Pretty good show, art is different and stylish, characters are fun and interesting, it's probably the most interesting ping pong will ever be in it's lifetime. Don't let the art put you off, nor the fact that it's about ping pong, the characters really do carry the show pretty hard, so that in itself should say how well they were written in. The ping pong scenes in themselves were actually not that bad, the art made it fun and the characters made it even better. So needless to say, if this show has slightly piqued your interest, I would say defiantly give it a shot.
                  First couple episodes should be enough to reel you in with its fun nature.
Story:
On the outside the story looks like it's about a couple of kids who want to play ping pong and win a tournament, but there are different little plots within the short 11 episode series. Each character has their own drive to play, some to win, and some to fill other dreams. It's beautifully achieved over the short span of just a few episodes, and I felt satisfied with it all at the very end. Without saying to much to anyone who has yet to see it, just imagine ping pong but interesting. I promise you, it's interesting.
Characters:
Now I know I've said this a lot in the top introduction, but the characters are superb! Like I said earlier, each character has their own drive to play the game, and there really is development within the few short episodes. The pacing for their development isn't rushed, nor is it too slow, it is just right. The comedy in this show is presented pretty well through their personality and actions, as well as the drama and action scenes. The style fits perfectly well with the characters in the show, and it's lovely.
Art:
The art is, different, as one could tell right away from just looking at the cover. I'm sure the art is what grabs peoples attention the most, which on that note I would like to say the art is amazing. I know the art puts most people off, and I want to say please don't let it put you off. It's easy to look past because there are other things in the show that would 'make up' for it. If you're one for art this show is awesome, and a need to watch. If art isn't priority, let this be your first artistic show, because it is actually interesting. Also I want to add that the music is great, I didn't really catch any annoying tune being used more than once, and if there were reused songs they were at least good songs. 
So overall this show is fantastic, look into it for a bit then dive straight into the world of ping pong!

The animation in this show was amazing and worth the watch purely for its style. I love seeing anime that pushes the boundaries of convention in a way that is artistic, Ping Pong did just that. There were some breathtaking scenes that were matched by incredible sound design and score. 
Each character design was unique, the voice acting was good (though I felt they cast a little too old for some of the characters who are supposed to be teenagers) and I definitely got a strong sense for who everyone was by the end of this short show. 
The problem I had with it was
                  simply the story wasn't quite engaging enough for me. It was decent enough and I liked the characters, but I didn't feel truly connected to any one individual. It felt like a collection of character studies, which were great, but when the only thing that stitches them together is ping pong it's hard to get truly invested in the overall story.
Saying that, I thoroughly enjoyed watching Ping Pong, but for me it was a good "one watch" type show.

This show is obviously very good. I give it an 8, but I can see why others give it a 9 or 10. 7, on the other hand, is too low. Here's why:
To me, 8, 9, and 10 means, this show is a cut above usual anime. The reason I cannot accept a 7 on Ping Pong the Animation is simply because Ping Pong the Animation is CLEARLY one of those anime that is just *built different.* The ingenuity in the animation is incredible. The style itself is unique as a hallmark of the show's director, but it also feels throughout that Ping Pong brings
                  out its style's fullest potential. This may be a rarity, but I don't think that there is any show better suited to Ping Pong's style than Ping Pong, nor that any style is better suited to Ping Pong than Ping Pong's style. 
As far as quality of story and character go, Ping Pong is most comparable to season 1 of Megalobox. That is to say, they work, but they don't break ground. They aren't really the centerpiece of the show. The substance of Ping Pong is not in the writing. 
It'd be a disservice to talk too much about the art and sound to an audience that hasn't experienced the show yet. Experience it for yourself.

Tsukimoto, aka 'Smile', and Hoshino, aka 'Peco', are two childhood friends who grew with the a certain talent for table tennis. As the grow, they keep playing ping pong: Peco become an very good player and Tsukimoto remains an average/good player. Their vision of ping pong changes when a chinese player, Wenge, plays with Peco and defeats him. Peco starts an introspection after this and Smile begins to invest himself in ping pong. This anime deals with several themes as dedication, work, depression, hesitation, hope and has a multicolor palette of subjects, the ping pong is only a way to communicate these feelings.
Each character of
                  this anime go through the feelings exposed earlier, giving them a real depth and resulting in a real attachment. This evolution of each character is the quintessence of Ping Pong the Animation.
The art of Ping Pong the Animation is quite particular for an anime, but your eyes will be soon adapted and you will fully appreciate it. Despite appearing ugly at first sight, the animation reveals itself to be very fluid and never careless, contrary to Devilman Crybaby for example, of the same art director.
The OST is pretty catchy, especially the 'Hero theme' which stands for Smile's determination and intern battle. Each character has his own theme which reflect his own personality.  
I really enjoyed this anime, it belongs to the kind of anime which change drastically your way to things and to view your life, and that's why I greatly encourage you to watch it, it's definitely worth it

The Hero Appears! The Hero Appears! The Hero Appears!
Chant these words three times in your mind! If you do that, I’ll come to you. Ping Pong the Animation is just more than a sports anime, it’s an anime about teenagers trying to find themselves through the game of ping pong. Each character is well fleshed out and serves a purpose. Even an easily forgettable character traveled all over the world to find himself. The story isn’t limited to our main characters only, we see glimpses of others and their struggles. The animation might look bland at a first glance but the more you see the
                  more it makes sense. After all, it was directed by none other than my man Masaaki Yuasa. He has a distinct way of telling a story and his art style is true to his feelings. The animation is very fluid and everything is held together by the alluring soundtracks. It has a nice after-taste. The more you think about it the better it gets.

smile+pico+dragon+akuma+kong+ping pong+art+opening= 10/10
Story:      9/10    Although it's an anime about ping pong, I find it more focused on character description, you see from episode 1 to end of episode 11 .................. You can only say wow.
Art:       10/10    Do I need to talk about this anymore?
Sound:      10/10  The opening, oh the opening, so good. the Sound makes you feel good to be nervous, sad, happy, confused. What more do you expect?
Character:   10/10   Each character is interesting, as I
                  said above, this anime reveals each character in different angles so that you will not hate the character at all but you understand and sympathize with them. 
Enjoyment: 9/10     I watch this anime at noon and feel so peaceful.
How do I mark this anime so high? Because it is a masterpiece......
"Chant these words three times in your mind!
"Hero kenzan!" "Hero kenzan!" "Hero kenzan!" 
Do that, and I'll come to you!"

Ping pong the animation is a story about ping pong used to discover some deeper things within each character.
Story 9:  The story is about how a bunch of very well developed characters use ping pong to show their feelings. While ping pong is what is going on all the time in this show it is surprisingly not really the point of it.
Art 8: The art is definitely unique. It has the same effect as some lo-fi music has in being charming because its not the average perception of beauty. It's a totally different style that not everyone is going to enjoy. I personally liked
                  it and found it pleasant to look at which the fluent animation helped.
Sound 10: The sound design is absolutely amazing. The soundtrack is the single best anime OST I have heard. Voice acting is also very well done with an interesting dynamic of the Chinese characters.
Characters 10: The characters are what make this show so great. There is a surprising amount of development for an 11 episode show. Each character is very unique which makes it easy to debate with your friends what characters from other anime, shows, or even super smash bros melee players are what certain character from ping pong. 
Enjoyment 9: The show is very enjoyable with a good start and amazing final 4 or so episodes. There is a slight lull in the middle where more character development occurs and less important events occur. The ending episodes more than make up for this.
Overall 9: Ping pong the animation is amazing. With stellar characters and sound design and a unique art style it is one of the best shows I have had the pleasure of watching.

In my youth I had seen the manga for sale, but I never gave it the opportunity, but it caught my attention for some reason (big mistake). A few years passed and I was intrigued by the trailer for the live action Ping Pong movie, because they used a song by a legendary Japanese alternative band that I liked called Supercar, which some time later, some members of this band formed another called LAMA, together with Kensuke Ushio, despite that, I didn't see her at the time either (another big mistake). I recently started listening to the OST of Ping Pong The animation and I
                  was struck by "Hero Appears" and "Hero Theme", these songs drink a lot of the sound of LAMA and the OST in general I liked a lot. I said to myself, "Well, let's give the anime in this manga a try."
At first I thought it was the typical sports game, but as they tell you the story, the twists and turns it takes and the subtle depth in dealing with the human issues it deals with completely blew my mind.
One of the main themes that blew my mind was the theme of the hero and how the series was building it through the episodes. The theme of the hero is something that I have very well instilled since my childhood when I watched the Japanese robot series and Sentai on television. Although it sounds ridiculous to some people, in some way it has helped me to believe in myself or give me courage and strength in difficult times and thus achieve impossible things. This last time, as an adult, I have lost the passion and the way to do the things that I wish I could do. This series put me back on track to keep chasing those things that I used to love and I am enormously grateful to have seen this great anime.
Pin Pong The Animation represents that great legacy of more than 60 years of history that Japanese animation has included generations of children on the construction of the hero, that despite the defects and problems that we may have, we must not lose the will to believe in something that we really care so that it mobilizes us to pursue it. It does not matter that when you grow up you will not achieve what you want, because there are other paths in which you can explore, the important thing is to live the moment to the fullest and enjoy it, which is what this anime tries to tell you in a spectacular way.
After watching the series via streaming, I think I will buy the manga and the bluray, including the live action version because it is a masterpiece, the themes it deals with and how well the story is told.

Ping Pong the animation is one of those series that you know is special from the first glance, because just by looking at the animation quality it maintains you know that you will at least remember something from this series; However, the series surprises for things such as its music, narration, endearing characters and above all teaching (of which, possibly it is your conclusion of it). The characters are charismatic, have unique personalities, and learn badly about their mistakes and actions. A wonderful play with cynical animation.
Is a special serie about the "hero", the friendships and The relationships. And it's wonderful how he does it
                  because All characters are simple and complex in equal ways, because are humans and the humans are simple and complex.

This is my first review so it might not be great.
I enjoy sports shows but to me they have never been much more than entertaining, this show differs in that respect. I found myself invested in every character and I related to a lot of their struggles, they are written pretty much perfectly. I found myself really rooting for the characters to overcome their struggles and find their real passions and interests.  The music in this show especially in the first 9 episodes was incredible and really brought out whatever scene was on at the time. The art style was unique and refreshing, besides
                  a tad bit of cgi here and there the animation was great. I think the only real issue I have with this show is that it wasn't longer, a little length on the show would have allowed to see more of the action aspect. This is one of the best shows I have ever seen and I highly recommend it to anyone even if they have no interest in ping pong.

(This is a spoiler-free review for anyone interested in watching the anime) 
⍟
⍟
⍟
I don’t usually write reviews, but this anime surprised me a lot, just to say the least. 
To be completely honest, while watching the first few minutes of the first episode, I had a strong urge to just stop and drop the anime just because of its art style. I wasn't fond of it and didn't find it pleasing to watch at all. However, as the minutes went by, I found myself so immersed that I totally forgot about what bothered me in the first place. After the end of each episode, I
                  kept wanting to watch more no matter the art style. And even more surprisingly, as I kept watching it, the story was so captivating that it even made the art style grow on me, as I saw it complementing the story so well. This tells you how much good of a story this is. This is what every story should aspire to be. Invest you into the story so much to the point you find yourself forgetting about anything that you disliked (If you even did in the first place). Making you realize how good it actually is by showing you how each element complements one another so seamlessly: story, style and music. Making you then certain, that there isn't anything wrong or bad in it, but instead just an amazing example of visual storytelling. 
So to give an advice to anyone reading this who's on the fence in watching it due to its art style. I would like to tell you without a doubt to watch it. It doesn't matter if you're into Ping Pong or not, or if you like the style or not. I can promise you that at the end of the day, you'll find yourself watching an amazing story that will truly resonate with you. This is not just a story about Ping Pong, it's a story about humans finding themselves and ultimately... learning how to fly.
🏓...

I have never done a review in this site, but this anime made me do one... What may look like a generic anime about sports ( Who thinks ping pong is brutally awesome, you know?) with an awfull art ends up being one of the most harmonic pieces of art i have experienced... The fact that this short anime is so "underground" is quite sad, in my opinion. Everything fits in each episode: the desing and art matches the flow and feel of the anime, as if the whole series was just an animated sketch, but instead of giving a vibe of
                  half-assed work, it gives an uniqueness to the anime.
   If you enjoy watching an anime that shows just how humans work, their flaws and ambitions and how that can influence how happy you actually are, while also enjoying some intense ping pong matches listening to a very well composed  soundtrack, do not miss this anime!

The art of this anime was a lot different than anything I watched before, at first I thought i wouldn't enjoy this but then I patiently watched some more episodes and I started loving this anime, I liked this anime because I got to know lot of stuff about ping pong which I didn't know before like the different kinds of grips ,different kinds of rubber and all that .
The best part of the anime was the ending song which I really liked other than that I liked the story and development of characters, The art didn't really matter to me because the story and
                  development of characters was very good.
This anime teaches us that we can pull ourselves from the bad situations if we are involved in healthy competition and that one should not abandon doing what they love or what they are good at for losing in it once or twice.
I liked the character of Kong Wenge and Kazama because of  the kind of change they undergo throughout the anime.
The ending was emotional and it wasn't the kind of ending that I was expecting but I was all satisfied with the ending and I would like to suggest people who are demotivated to watch this anime , this stuff is really motivational. 
I am giving 5 points to the animation because I am not really sure about how I felt about the animation, I liked the art but I am not sure if I can really give points for this animation. I loved the sounds in this and the characters but the thing I liked the most has to be the ending song.

Ping-pong is a rather odd show when looking at it from outside, mostly due to the shows art style and the sport the the character play ping-pong. I mean ping-pong is fun and all, but when people talk about sports especially professional sports I doubt that ping-pong would be the first thing that they would think of. Still that’s the part of the show that the story and character gravitate around which are the factors that make this show a blast to watch.
Without looking really to into it the show is rather straightforward as it follows two childhood friends and ping-pong players as they go
                  through their high school career of ping-pong. Both characters contrast each other with Tsukimoto “smiles” being a stoic and serious type who has no grand ambitions with playing ping-pong but plays nonetheless, and Hoshino “Peco” a more energetic and carefree type who lazes around but still has dreams of grandeur. Along the way they meet other players most notable being Kong and Kazuma who not only serve as rivals/antagonists, but as other characters with their own motivations which shows due to how heavily the show also focuses on them. Still i don’t think the story itself is all that great since it just a series of ping-pong matches with very little at stake for the characters, a somewhat predictable storyline that becomes more obvious as the story continues, and some absurdities that really can take you off the show. However it does help that the show doesn't focus just on the sport, but also the character, their interactions,and their purpose. 
Each of the characters go through their own trials whether it leads to success or failure, and how they are able to cope with it. It’s through the coping that the characters develop gaining new insight in life and purpose. Characters that seem like asses are given depth and growth that they become more endearing as the show goes along. Even when two known characters are matched against each other, and it’s obvious who’s going to win. It’s disheartening to see the other player lose. Sometimes.  Still i wished they expanded on some of the side characters because it’s evident that something there that can be looked into, but is just kind of passed aside. 
Yes, the artstyle does look very weird, and personally i thought i would have a hard time adjusting to it, but i actually found it rather easy to get used to. Still it does look silly, especially the character designs, and the animation in a traditional sense isn’t that good as well. However as the show goes along it’s really hard to imagine the show looking any other way but this. The show uses the style to an effective degree to convey a message that’s easy to grasp via visuals alone. 
The soundtrack for the show is alright i guess but nothing noticeable outside the ping-pong matches except when the characters sing during christmas, and the sound of ping-pong creating some sort of rhythm. The voice acting for the show however was good with everyone doing an exceptional roles with maybe a few jarring voices coming from some of the side characters.
Overall i really did enjoy the show. Despite it’s short run time of 11 episodes it was able to present a great cast of characters, and a quick story that doesn’t overstay its welcome.

Being the 3rd sports anime I watched, after Haikyuu and Run with the Wind, I was in for a totally different style in both art, pace and tone of the series. Compared to the rating of the series, I was disappointed
Story 7/10: The story is rather weird at times. Focusing on character less important than the main characters, which makes me feel I'm following the main characters in 3rd person. Also many scenes seems irrelevant for such a short series. It could have been spent showing more about table tennis, that feels rather unimportant, when games are skipped quickly mostly just showing some clips, and
                  skipping to result. No character thoughts or progress trough a game. General pacing is often confusing and the watcher has to figure out himself when a timeskip suddenly apears several times out of nowhere. The power level of some charcter just shifts very quickly for weird reasons. And one of main characters seemingly so strong, yet seems to have no interest in table tennis.
Art 5/10: So, the art of this series is probably a love or hate for many. I did not like it at all. It reminds me of Attack on Titans art from the ugly titans, and it just gets you down, rather than excited. The pace of some scenes become way to fast, while the art is also very unclear and blurry, makes it hard to enjoy. Hardly ever seen clear character face expressions. The only positive about the art is some of the animation techniques used. Others, like the multi split screen, doesn't work very well often.
Sound 7/10: I'm not a big fan of the opening theme, compared to the ending. Guess it's just taste. Most of the characters where male and the conversations are very dull, which sets a very unentusiastic conversational tone. Also at one point there is this annoying battle music whenever the Kano players are shown. One refreshing positive note is the actual chinese and english spoken by the characters, rather than only japanese.
Character 8/10: Characters are some of the only bright part about this series. And feels like the creator builds the series around these. 
Enjoyment 6/10: The whole tone of the series, from the start is very dark and depressing compared to other sports anime. All the characters are negative (except Peco), they boast and talk shit, making players feel like shit and qutting Table Tennis (including me wanting to quit watching) There are very few female characters (like 2x5 seconds in the first 4 episodes) which makes only hearing angry young males complain for over an hour constantly, just a bit over the top. I did not get hooked, and pushed myself to push trough every episode, which is not good for anime.
Overall 7/10

I was someone who hesitated watching this show for a long time. The animation seemed horrible and the whole concept of Ping Pong as an anime was strange to me. Somehow, it not only exceeded my expectations but has made an impact on my life. I have been anxious about my life in sports for a long time since i missed out on going pro and this show has really helped this anxiety. It has made me realize that you should enjoy the times for what they were and to keep moving forward. The animation will take some getting used to but fits really well
                  with the story. The story is generic in a Unique way. The classic sports anime trope is there but it feels fresh. They characters also seem kinda bland at first, especially Smile, but he grows on you. Everything about this show becomes better and better everytime you rewatch. I can't recommend this enough for people with performance anxiety or people who are looking for meaning in life.

[Spoiler Free Review]
Ping Pong the Animation is what I would consider a perfect show. I don't like to call things perfect but PPTA checks all the boxes. The amount of emotion, character, and story fit into just 11 episodes is astounding. In these few short episodes lies the greatest coming of age story I have witnessed.
The first thing I want to address, the elephant in the room, the art style. I can't argue for an art style and convince you that it is good but I can explain why I love it. I feel like PPTA's art style perfectly complements the emotions the show emits.
                  These simple monotone drawings with light pastel backgrounds complement each other so well in this style of animation. You can truly feel the pulse of each character and each match through the vibrant animation. The art feels so meek and shy which is very fitting for PPTA, being a very intrinsic experience at times, despite this the animation will always breath life in to every scene better than any fancy art style could have done for this show.
There is no true "main character" in PPTA, each character gets developed like they are the focus, and if it weren't for screen time it would be impossible to tell. However, the 4 most important leads are defiantly Smile, Peco, Dragon, and Kong. Each character goes through a wildly different character arc despite them all playing the same game. Each character in this story works as a counteracting force to another, which leads to conflict and development. Characters are shot down for others to fly, but one man's failure will always lead to his eventual success. Even the most insignificant characters will get development, development that is unheard of in such a short time frame.
Themes in PPTA are the driving force behind its greatness. PPTA is written much like a book, using a plethora of symbolism, irony, and other rhetorical devices that create such dense themes. Each character represents another different theme; Loneliness, Overconfidence, Failure, Shame, Selfishness, Humility. This show will have you feel so much emotion for every character. 
The plot is really captivating; Its crazy how invested I got in these tournaments. This plot feels realistic despite it centering around a sport. What's great about the conflict in this show is that you can't predict what will happen. Many times while watching I got fooled in to thinking there would be an obvious winner, which really adds to the realism. This is because all these characters are is just a group of kids. The plot's climax in tension is at episode 6 which is the start of a narrative shift in the show. Episode 6 is my favorite anime episode of all time but I digress. This is the point where each character faces their hardest struggles, each struggling with something specific to them. After this halfway point all of the character's finish their development and everything ends, beautifully.
There's not much more I can say without spoiling but do yourself a favor and watch Ping Pong the Animation.

In terms of sports anime, this is another excellent one. It's clear that this anime is a creation out of passion for art and for sport. The charts and diagrams and the dynamic poses and stunning strokes..! The rhythm of the animated ping pong matches was so lively, the ping-pong equipment talk was SO NERDY, the animating team clearly did their research!
The music is SO thematic and sets the tone excellently, there are constant pop-culture references (Akira!!! NGE!!!), and the animation ... wow... This is anime, visually, at its finest. Exaggerated motions, blurs and smears, so much use of contrast. There was a scene with
                  a flashlight and the RESPECT that the animating team had for light and dark in that scene.... Perspective was just wild, no rules just guidelines, and combined with a moving "camera"....!!!!!! There was a variety of textures, the colors were interesting and moody, and the way they drew out split-second moments, it's almost undescribable.. the athletes would be running fast while the scene passes in slow motion, only anime could make that look right lol
There was one thing I really didn't like about this anime. Not like it's a huge flaw or anything, but I guess the characters bored me. They would just offer their short monologues while joining their peers for a thousand-yard-stare, or be yelling about how passionate they are, or they would just. leave. just cuz fuck you i guess. It was hard for me to keep watching this one, because of the dialogue being too boring or too confusing for me to follow. There are MANY characters from different schools, and the anime often cuts very quickly. There are also frequent semi-metaphorical flashbacks and personally i found that confusing and unhelpful, but yknow, the music and animation teams carried still. It's all very anime!!!! I enjoyed it despite my confusion! Maybe if I watch a second time, I will be able to keep track of all the characters and their relationships to each other..... We'll see haha
Similar anime, cuz i love sports anime: 
Hajime no Ippo- also very individualistic, sports anime about boxing, however this one builds up the interpersonal relationships and the warmth much much better, though it's a much slower paced show as a result. 
Haikyuu- This one is a lot less individualistic, a lot less artistically talented, way longer, and way way cuter. That's it it's just kawaii cute haha
If your passion is closer to writing and storytelling, I think you might find this one to be a little disappointing, tho maybe it'd be a fun study! Every beautiful work has room for improvement!
All in all, Ping Pong the Animation is a GREAT anime to watch for your viewing pleasure, and for animation buffs i recommend: "Probably should watch it! Just to know how good this shit can get." This is a unique watch! Don't miss out!

i cannot overstate just how much i love this show. i think it's the epitome of a modern masterpiece. sports and anime are such a match made in genre pairing heaven. the animation style is so distinct and unique. the stories elegant and nuanced. sports streamline so much of the necessary pretension of the medium into something comprehensible and immediate. while i think they could've pushed the character development into something slightly more unique areas, it is such a trivial concern it barely impacted my enjoyment of the series. a high watermark in contemporary anime. it's wild to consider it's as old as it is
                  (7 years at the time of writing).

Ping Pong the Animation is one of the best sports anime out there. Even tho i haven't watched alot of sports anime I can directly tell that this one is very good.

Character--> 10   I really loved the characters in this anime. I always love to see an introvert-extrovert couple if you know what i mean. Also the character development of Smile was very great. He went from someone who doesn't care about winning to someone who reallly wants to win.

Thank you for rading this review.

Without any doubt that ping pong the animation is the greatest sports anime of all time!
While other sports anime walk on tropes and clichés ping pong the animation strives on originality and great characters.
speaking of the characters the characters are phenomenal and you get to feel the points of view of every character and you get to root for all of them and get attached to them. the artiste is pretty to look at and flows like water. when character makes a decision I feels like a human made it and not a anime character like while i was watching I never went 'that was
                  stupid why would they do that' and they did it would be a rationale decision that anyone would make in the situation.
it truly is a phenomenal show and would highly recommend 10/10!

I want to like this show more than I actually do. First off, it’s racist (I’ll explain in the Writing section). I would have dropped the show by the end of episode 5 if it weren’t for Kong, my favorite character. Seeing that he reappears in episode 8 encouraged me to hang on. Episode 10, the second to last episode, was the first ostensible feeling of fun I had watching the show. Episode 11 then wrapped up the series in a satisfying manner. 
- Story. This show is 40% sports 60% character arcs. There were a couple revelations about character backgrounds and relationships that pleasantly
                  surprised me. However, the pacing was too slow. Half of the main and supporting cast are unlikeable for the first two thirds of the show. Kong and Akuma had the tightest narratives, with clear motivations and actions resulting from their internal struggles. The others had several logical inconsistencies that got in the way of convincing storytelling even though I understood what the show was trying to say with each of them.
It follows that the payoff of episodes 10 and 11 took too long to arrive. In my opinion, there was enough imagery and foreshadowing that 2-3 episodes’ worth of B-roll and extraneous side plots (such as one character’s weird incest romance, or a mere background character's soul searching journey) could have been cut. It was not worth my time sitting there waiting for things to “get good” between Kong episodes.
- Characters. Each character grapples with what ping pong means to them. Why do they work so hard to train? Why do they want to win? Why do they like to play? Do they like to play? Who are they playing for? The answer is rooted in their individual pasts and life experiences.
Kong is the star of the show for me. He faces high stakes pressure fueling his desire to win. What is most compelling, however, is how he deals with his trials and tribulations. He changes so much as a person by the end of the show. His reasons for change are open to interpretation, but I think the show gives me enough information to come to a conclusion that makes sense to me.
- Art. The lineart style is exceedingly HIDEOUS! In fact, the lineart is so poor that a character who changed his fashion sense was literally unrecognizable until another character said their name. It made me realize there are basically no character models for faces. As for the colors, I liked the pastel-like shading style. It made some background scenes look really nice. 
- Animation. Decent for a lower budget show. It is rough around the edges, yet it fits the unhinged art style. There is some weird 3-D CGI, but I think the team did the best that they could. They made interesting stylistic choices such as animating an actual arrow as the ball travels between players. I was worried about the recycled animations, but there was only one episode in which I fast forwarded through them.
- Music. I thought the soundtrack (synthwave/electronic vibes) was fantastic. The use of the music transformed the mood of the scenes. 
- Sound design. The actual selection of sounds was fine, but I noticed several moments where the sound didn’t sync to the animation. Most frequently, a shoe would skid on screen and the sound came late.
- Writing. What's up with the casual racism? Kong is referred to as “China” throughout the show. Not “that Chinese guy” or “Chinese player”, just China, as in the entire country. While they called him China less frequently out loud as the show progressed, they still referred to him as China in writing on screen and then once more in episode 8. While his Chinese identity is part of his character development, I don't care for this offensive delivery. Early on, they also threw in a stereotype about black people being good at dancing, in order to combat stereotypes (the irony). Who greenlit this? I expected better from 2014.
Even though relationships are supposed to be a core theme of this show, several depictions did not make sense. Without giving too much away, the friends in this show seemed to support each other less than their rivals/antagonists. It was hard to believe the utter dearth of empathy between two characters when they were extremely close childhood friends. Their supposed fallout was not properly explained (I wasn’t buying the one-liner provided in the show). Furthermore, Peco and Smile’s team has zero camaraderie - we constantly see the bad blood between seniors and first years -- and somehow they are on good terms at the end. The seniors had even expressed their bitterness at being neglected by their own coach, who focused all his energy on developing Smile.
Smile and his own coach’s relationship was also unconvincing in comparison to Kong and Peco’s relationships with their coaches. I do not understand where Smile and his coach began trusting each other and working together. His coach seems more interested in beating the competitive drive into Smile instead of drawing out Smile’s intrinsic motivation.
Speaking of character motivations, a couple of main characters had confusing turning points in their motivation. I could identify that there was supposed to be a catalyst, but not what it was in the scene. I had to look up other people’s interpretations online because the show didn't leave enough breadcrumbs to figure it out myself. 
For some reason, this show likes to tell you all about Smile’s prowess rather than show it as it does for the other skilled players. It was irksome to hear a side character remark for the umpteenth time that Smile was a ping pong monster murder machine. I think we got it the first time, and the second time, and the third time, as they played robot noises synced to his movements… His matches were boring and predictable.

I think most people have already said everything there is to say about it, but for the sake of myself, I'm just going to write down what I remember.
I've seen this twice now, and I can reassure myself that I enjoy this one.  I will usually recommend it to people that don't particularly like anime, or specifically sport anime, as I feel like it was a good intro for me.  I think that people overhype it though, it's good no doubt but the story is kinda... it leaves a lot to be desired.  It goes along fairly well, but I wasn't wowed
                  like I initially was the second time around.  I think there are better stories for sure, but the art and animation really carry it so it's excusable.  Not saying there are any plot holes, but it feels a little bare (maybe I just don't have quite the same taste for sports anime anymore).

Ping Pong the Animation feels like it was tailor-made for me. It tells the story of 5 table tennis competitors in a period of two years, and concludes it with an epilogue 10 or smt years later. And all is creative choices are made in order to develop those 5 characters, so that they come of age. Poignant af, and especially relatable to me, because I used to be a precocious depressed math competitor, PPTA really hit home. To top it all off, this anime does not feature any of that shitty anime comedy that makes me inhale slowly and sigh with regret.
I would love
                  to praise every aspect of this anime to high heaven, but I feel it would be redundant and inappropriate, because I adore it so much. When one loves something, trying to objectively analyze it sounds stupid, self-indulging and superficial (looking at you, anime youtubers) Still, I am obligated to say for the sake of promotion that the Tenderness and China OSTs make me tear up every time (post-PPTA.) Kensuke Ushio is my Final Fantasy VII.
Just watch it. You might feel like everything you have seen before is BS post-PPTA (sports anime are now all the same BS to me );) so be warned. If the animation is putting you off, know that it put me off when it came out in 2014 as well and l was retarded back then. PPTA's style grew on me a lot because I liked the show. While watching it, surprisingly I never found it ugly, or too quirky. I get it too, if the sports anime story is typically not your thing - it isn't mine either. However, know that PPTA is a sports anime only when it comes down to the setup, tropes, and epic moments. At the heart of it, the anime is about 5 lovable goofballs, 3 cute old timers, numerous losers that don't matter (but make you cry nonetheless,) and the drama between them. Ping Pong the Animation is a love letter to table tennis and a tribute to youth.

idk if its only because i just finished watching the last episode, but ive been watching this anime slowly enough that i can be sure im not giving it such a high rating based purely on my feeling right after watching it :P
i went into this like "ah i heard the animation is outstanding and beautiful, i guess its worth a shot" bc i dont watch sport anime, i have never seen the appeal and i dont like watching sports so why would i wanna watch a sport anime right..? Well ....... this is so much more
ping pong the animation is seemingly about ping pong
                  but under the facade of "sport anime" you get a beautiful story with lovable characters and touching moments.. ive cried too many times while watching this anime during moments im not even sure i was supposed to cry in
this is a story about well... life, and what i really loved about it is that its not trying to be dramatic or special or extraordinary or anything like that. you have tsukimoto and hoshino - two extraordinary table tennis players, but their environment, their life, everything else about them is just normal. theyre human and i love that
the way all the characters are drawn is much more realistic than average anime, and doesnt make the characters especially attractive. its not trying to make anything look pretty -- until they start playing table tennis
the animation and movements are AMAZING and i enjoyed watching the matches for the animation alone, except theres so much more depth to every match, it means so much more than just table tennis, each character has their own struggles and expectations from themselves - and it really made me see myself in them, in their one-of-a-kind personalities despite their ordinary lifestyle, in their mistakes and desicions.
the last thing i want to say about the story is .. its about friendship, more than anything. it starts off with friendship and ends with friendship, its about friends helping each other out, making each other smile, pushing each other to the limit when no one else would and at the end just being there for each other
its so well crafted, every single episode, and it makes you stick your eyes to the screen out of fear of missing anything...!!!!! its the best anime ive watched in a really long time and as i moved thru the episodes i knew i had to add it to my favorites because frankly ive never seen animation like that in Any other anime !
watch ping pong the animation please i am begging you pleases pleas

Spoilers ahead.
This anime is good.
CHARACTERS
The characters are fleshed out. Their troubles hit close to home. 
Hoshino's sad state when he was demotivated is similar to how I feel sometimes. I'm glad he came out of that phase, it gives hope for me. 
I'm glad Kazama doesn't feel as stressed as before when thinking about ping pong. I would've liked to see the process and the realization. 
Some character changes felt rushed, like Sanada giving up his infatuation with the ad girl. 
STORY
The ending episode(s) felt weird:
- First, the final tournament. It feels like a lot less effort went into hiding the plot armor. I definitely felt weird after Hoshino beat Wenge and Kazama since they trained really hard, a lot more than Hoshino. Maybe it was to illustrate once again the importance of talent in winning.
- Second, the time-skip at the end. I'm glad there's a happy ending. I felt emotional. But I was a bit disappointed that it's like a happily ever after. Maybe it's better than a forced sad ending, I don't know. I'm glad all characters are doing well.
ART
Rough lines made for more dynamic feel, sometimes. 
It helps also that I didn't find any of the characters attractive just because of how they look. If I did, it was because of who they were.
SOUND
Opening has some lyrics that make me emotional when I see them.
ENJOYMENT
It's 3:46 am as I write this as I finished watching the anime. 
Definitely the emotions are stronger because I'm in a though spot. I have a lot of responsibilities I've ran away from that are on the verge of collapsing on me. 
I empathized on a hard level with the characters and I hope I can stop running away. 
OVERALL
A great watch. The characters are well developed. There are many lessons to be taken too.
One quote that resonated with me was:
"The only way to be sure you won't lose is to not fight." 
- Sakuma to Hoshino. Episode 4. 8:57.

Hero? Do you believe in heroes? Those who arrives when you call them, the hero comes, the hero comes, the hero comes Chant these words in your mind, and I'll surely come to you...
After i got in mind that the sport genre = gay, this anime changed my mind forever, the masterpiece of the genre, i have never tought that an anime about ping pong would be so interesting.
Just fast commentaries, this anime will make feel like if you were a kid, the innocent believe in heroes, the heroes with no weaks, the heroes who saves you when you call them. Two characters totally different
                  and not conventional, in a story that gets you since the first chapter, a awesome travel about personal growth, the innate talent, the hard work and more, in just  11 chapters.
A unique art style, and a great soundtrack, why haven't you watched it?

I have to say this was one of my favorite animes I've watched in a long time, absolutely wonderful and memorable one.
The animation is weird, and it can be both ugly and beautiful from one second to the next, without breaking any flow or sticking out. The animation might be a hard sell for some people, but the way it's use is definitely allows for both some fantastical and yet also realistic visuals. Blew me away at moments yet keeps things grounded for the more serious scenes.
The sound/music is absolutely wonderful, if I have to rate the soundtrack I would put it in my top
                  5 favorite anime soundtracks of all time. Everything about the soundtrack is perfect for the series, and I had some of the songs stuck in my head for the past few days since I've finished the series.
The characters are absolutely amazing, all of them coming together over the intensity and love of Ping Pong, or also what Ping Pong represents to them. I can't give away any of the plot, but I feel like almost every character was memorable in this series, or played a purpose in the plot.
Should also give a shout out to voice acting, honestly had some of the most amazing/naturalist voice acting I've seen from an anime. The characters are totally believable in delivering their lines, there's two characters who speaks both Japanese and Chinese and they nail both languages and the acting so wonderfully that I was amazed. What's painful is that apparently they and some of the other voice actors haven't gotten more roles in anime, they're clearly talented and amazing based off just the work they put into this series alone.
Overall, this series is a classic. I had been putting it off for so long before finally buckling down to finish it, and I don't regret it one bit.

--This review contains major spoilers, read the TLDR if you don't want spoilers--
--TLDR--
Ping pong the animation is a masterpiece. The animation does look a bit weird but trust me, this is not your average generic sport show. Watch it.
--Spoilers onwards--
What does it take for a sport story to be perfect? Well look at ping pong the animation. It is one of the best if not the best sport anime in history. 
Well, why? First of all, the story. Sure, you can say that ping pong the animation is just playing at tournaments, but it's much more deeper than that. Tsukimoto is someone who is talented
                  at ping pong, but cares more about other people. When he goes to a tournament, he meets Kong Wenge, who wants to meet his family. When he sees Wenge getting annoyed by his coach when Tsukimoto is about to win, he just loses... not for his sake... but for Wenge's sake. Unlike your typical cliché in sport anime where the MC is able to get overpowered and win the match, Tsukimoto lost on purpose for someone's sake. This is an example of proper writing and not using the same cliché over and over. Well, what else is there? The Kazama match with Peco. Kazama originally was just some super super strong dude who cared for his team, but he figured something in his match with Peco. Fun. That's right. Something so simple. So how? We get to see Kazama developing from this match where he's struggling, to a match where he doesn't care whether he loses or not, and just wants to have fun. And finally, one of the greatest ways to end sport anime IF not the best. Peco and Tsukimoto in the final. Flashbacks of Tsukimoto and Peco's childhood were shown, even adding more emotion. And guess what. Another thing that ping pong the animation does different than your usual sport Shonen; the MC just wanting to have fun with his best friend even if they lost.
That's all what Tsukimoto wanted to do. Going against a match with Peco in a fun all out match. That's all he wanted. This is absolutely perfect. I'm not even giving the story a 9.9/10, it's a definite 10/10.
While the story in ping pong the animation is magnificent, the art feels a bit weird. Racquets look a bit wonky; faces look a bit off; and the ping pong balls seem a bit weird. Other than that, the art is honestly pretty solid. It's not perfect, but as ping pong the animation wouldn't be ping pong the animation without this art. A solid 7/10 for Art.
Sometimes the sound used in ping pong the animation is a bit out of sync (e.g the bat hitting the ping pong ball isn't on time). Even though, most of the sound used in ping pong the animation is pretty good and is on sync. Some of the sound worked better than your usual sound effects. The bat hitting the ball is perfect; it's exactly what I hear in real life. A high 9 out of 10 for sound.
Unlike your typical sport Shonen, the main character cares more about the opponent. Usually, the protagonist is a cocky kid who gets stronger and stronger; but that's set for another character in our show; Peco.
Tsukimoto, someone who wanted to hide and stay away from people.. "It's safe here. I want to stay here." He found a fun game called ping pong and loved playing it. 
The best part about Tsukimoto is that he doesn't care about himself in a ping pong game... he cares about the opponent. This is different from the usual main character, who cares about themselves more.
I will admit that Peco is a bit of a copy paste, because his character is a cocky teenager. He may be a copy-paste character but he's likeable.
Kazama was pretty much that one guy who was strong but wanted his team to be really good so they can win the tournament... his development with the battle against Peco was not rushed and perfect... experiencing a fun match in a while. Kazama is a great character.
Wenge was someone who wants to visit his parents which are in another country. He was playing ping pong for that. That was a really solid background. Wenge is a bit cocky but he thinks rationally and takes the right move... another great character.
10/10 for characters.
When it comes to ping pong (the sport) I enjoyed it. So I would expect to enjoy ping pong the animation, which I did. It may've been a bit slow at points, but I enjoyed this sport all the way to the final episode. The op was absolute rocking, while the ending was pretty chill. I loved both and made me want to sing it sometimes. 10/10 for enjoyment.
Ping pong the animation is different from your usual Shonen sports. It has a great sense of originality and different  art from your usual anime. What's more, the story came with perfect-timed character development and was perfect overall. 10/10 for ping pong the animation.

Art / Animation - Interesting and well suited artstyle with gorgeous use of animation to convey emotion, power or whatever else.  10/10
Sound / Music - My favourite OST to date with unique masterpieces like Ping pong phase 2 which uses the sounds of ping pong balls and shoe squeaking to make a great track. Songs are incredibly used for hype and emotion and not a single time is the music out of place. Sound and noise in general is also used to show how the characters are feeling as well in this show.  10/10
Characters / Development - All the characters are extremely strong
                  in this anime, and have vastly different backgrounds but you can empathise with any of them. They also all develop a ton in a realistic way for realistic reasons.  10/10
Plot - Fairly normal sports show plot, but it's fine since characters are more of the focus in this show. I did however really enjoy the ending and the little post show "what the characters are up to bit".  8/10
Enjoyment / Mood - With such great characters and music this show is one with emotional up and downs with some incredible hype moments, but just as importantly those "Oh shit" moments. Its not to binge and very enjoyable.  10/10
Overall - 10/10
Dub
Best Girl - Old Lady, when young

Ping Pong the animation is quite a unique sports and coming to age story. Honestly, the story is pretty normal, and if you've read enough stories, you would most likely know what was going on after episode 3. 
That said, the story isn't exactly important. It's more of the way the story is laid out and how characters get to the ending point. And it's pretty good. The art and sound are obviously amazing. OST and characters are very good, especially Peco's voice actor: spot on. Art is representative of Taiyou's artstyle (I looked up the manga), and looks great even when animated, despite being
                  completely different from standard and traditional art styles. Nothing to say about these two things. Just well made.
Really, the meat of the story is the characters and their progression. It's not that bad, but honestly, it's also not that great? Character personalities kind of go as they please, and a lot of the characters act very weirdly and randomly. Lots of focus is given to the wrong characters, but all in all, it's still fine. It's supported by great art and sound,  so it passes.
Overall, its pretty good. I was a little disappointing with how characters progressed, which I really did think could have been more well made. Perhaps that's also just a distinct creative liberty Taiyou has, but it does not mean I have to like it, obviously. It's hard for a review to give this show justice. You should just go check it out, it's worth a watch.

For those put off by the art style, please give this one a shot. The style was initially offputting to me, but, after a few episodes, it really stuck and even enhanced my experience by the end. The story focuses on characters on the spectrums of talent, hard work, and love of a game, and how characters in different places of these spectrums can be silently suffering and find relief. Overall, the themes explored here really reminded me of Good Will Hunting, but, for me, Ping Pong lands at a much more balanced and cathartic conclusion to the questions of "what does it mean to
                  have talent?" and "who do you play table tennis for?".

Alright. Ping Pong the animation was a fantastic show.
For me , this show wasn't about ping pong but about the story of tsukimoto and peco and ping pong just happened to be a part of their story. 
Ping pong gives you insights into lives of different types of players and the way they look at that sport.
It 's greatest strength is it's characters. From different players like Smile ,  peco to even coaches like koizumi. It focuses on everyone and they all provide major contributions to the story.
Masaaki Yuuasa's unique style of storytelling is quite clearly visible in this anime as well.
Some shots in
                  the anime during matches feel like they're literally panels taken out of a manga the way our screen is divided into 3 or 4 parts. A character that I personally loved in the series was kong wenge. The music was great as well. Especially loved the "hero" song in the finale. 
So overall summing up this review, this anime was about tsukimoto calling out his hero for years and what happens when that hero returns.
Story 	9
Animation 	9
Sound 	10
Character 	10
Enjoyment 	9

Ping Pong the Animation traz uma excelente história com profundidade, ótima construção de personagens e mensagens bem realistas sobre seu mundo. Diferentemente de outras obras populares, PPtA não procura trazer o velho clichê que "se você se esforçar tudo é possível", o mundo real não é um mar de rosas, principalmente em esportes de alto rendimento onde o prodígio lapidado com dedicação sobressai qualquer esforçado sem talento. A dura realidade dos esportes.
Não apenas sobre ping pong, PPtA entrega com competência relações exteriores ao jogo. Namoro, trabalho, família, tudo isso é bem explorado sob medida sem perder o foco no principal que é o esporte.
Hoshino e
                  Tsukimoto representam o velho dueto impulsivo/emotivo vs. inteligente/calculista. A vida de ambos e os flashbacks que justificam suas personalidades e motivações atuais é bem trabalhada e o protagonismo é bem revezado entre ambos durante a obra, sendo particularmente um deleite para meus olhos.
Por estes e outros motivos a história de PPtA é facilmente um 10. Mas por que não posso dar um 10? Simples e óbvio: a animação.
Se pudéssemos fazer uma analogia da obra como um todo eu compararia PPtA com um ambiente extremamente agradável, aconchegante e convidativo com um esgoto à céu aberto ao lado. A incrível história de PPtA é capaz de te conduzir a fazer vista grossa para a animação, com toda a razão. Mas ela está lá sempre evidente principalmente em momentos de ação como nos jogos, muitas vezes com frames parados e com pouca diferenciação entre um jogo principal e um ordinário, entregando pouca clareza do que realmente está acontecendo ali. Tudo é mal desenhado e inconsistente, inclusive personagens de primeiro plano. Não bastando isto, multidões e outros elementos que compõem o plano de fundo são horripilantes. Como único ponto positivo digo que a perspectiva e o enquadramento surpreendentemente são competentes e tornam uma cena ruim em aceitável.
Infelizmente existem muitos animes com excelente animação e uma história porca e cheia de fanservices, enquanto outros têm uma história fascinante para contar, porém sem uma animação à altura para entregar todo seu potencial. PPtA encaixa no segundo tipo.

Ping pong the animation:
What does sport mean to you?
You can tell me you want to be on top of the world, a fun hobby or even reduce it to the stereotype of "It's just talent". In a narrative where the heroes don't actually exist to save you, but give you the chance to save yourself and show your abilities, your weaknesses, your disappointments and certainly the most beautiful thing about you, Matsumoto brings us a work that demonstrates how something as trivial as our love for something can reflect on our persona.
As we are shown the face of the character egami, who after a crushing
                  defeat to Tsukimoto tries to seek a journey of self-knowledge and ends up realizing how wrong was his decision to abandon the sport. It is noticed that both victory and defeat can have an equal weight for the athlete, making such thoughts as arrogance, arrogance, lack of skill is a reason to continue in such activity, being notorious both in mediocre players and those with enviable gift.
Friendship, hate, envy, uncertainties will be present in the life of the one who has decided to dedicate his life to something he really likes and even more for the one who lies to himself about his feelings in relation to what he really wants to do.
Finally, that you can really enjoy the best experiences with teammates or even opponents within something you wanted to do yourself. So that we can be our own heroes who will come to save us.

I came to watch this anime after learning that it was done by the same guy who directed "Tatami Galaxy" and I really fucking liked that anime. The way it ended and the overall message behind it was wonderful. So, naturally I had high hopes for this one too as it was even above in rating than Tatami Galaxy, but I have to say that I am a little bit disappointed.
The anime started out great and I was really loving the 'hero' part as it reminded me of "The Magnificent Steiner" from Monster. It really does depict properly both sides of winning and losing. Everyone
                  has reasons to win, everyone faces repercussions on losing, it's true. Some lose their way after losing like Hoshino while others try working harder for the next time like Tsukimoto aka Smile. It was fine until here but from here on out it starts to get really unrealistic which was really off-putting to me. While everyone is working their ass off day in and day out, Hoshino is lazing around and even starts to smoke! I found this really weird that he  just made up his mind to get back into the game and was able to recover just by working very hard. I get that he worked really hard, so much so that one of his knees gave out. This is my second major issue. A knee injury is not something that you can brush aside. No matter how much natural talent you may have, winning against a fucking olympic gold medalist is not an easy feat and if you have a knee injury it makes it exponentially difficult. But he ends up defeating Kazama. It was just for the sake of plot because he is a 'hero' and Kazama was in need of a 'hero' to help him. Then he beats Tsukimoto and goes on to play on an international level. 
So...Hoshino used his knee which was already a little busted to play against an olympic gold medaist and Tsukimoto who was just as good as him to win and it didn't cause any problems later on?! You have got to be kidding me. If  only the ending was a bit more realistic it could have been a 10/10 for me. Don't get me wrong I can get behind an unrealistic ending too but only in fantasy, not in a sports genre. Specially if it takes place in a setting such as this clearly depicting other people's hardwork, perseverance and aspirations. 
My score break up is:
Story: 6/10
Art: 9/10
Sound: 9/10
Character: 6/10
Enjoyment: 7/10
Overall: 7.4/10 => 7/10 on MAL

The first 5 minutes of the first episode are so important, they are what determines if people watch the show or drop it. And there is one moment in the first episode (2:50) where it sort of freezes on this dudes face and it looks horrible. It made me want to throw up. ok other anime have slow/boring first episodes like d-gray man, gintama, steins gate, princess Mononoke ect. but I have never been straight up disgusted by a first episode until I watched this. I can guarantee 99% of the people who watched this dropped it at the 3 minute mark bc of that
                  1 decision.  
And the rest of the anime has way better art, great animation (these matches were hype even though I was disappointed by how short the final match was) and looks way better. But it doesn't matter bc the first episode had terrible looking art and everyone dropped it. One punch man would never have been popular if the art was trash in episode 1, even if the rest of the anime was the same. The animation in this anime wasn't quite as good as One Punch Man (let's be honest, no show is) but it is pretty close. It feels like the entire episode is sakuga, it's sort of amazing. But it doesn't matter. First 5 minutes of the first episode, if you mess that up the rest of your anime is  irrelevant.

If you like coming of age stories than i recommend Ping Pong The Animation. I won't lie, the art is excruciatingly horrible but after not too long you get used to it and come to not mind it. The story is great. You have a main cast of about 4 characters, each which have their own inner conflicts and as the show goes on you dive deeper into them.
I wouldn't say this is a sports anime, more so an anime that uses sports as a gimmick to help push it's themes and metaphors and such. At 11 episodes you'll be able to get through it
                  fairly quickly.
Definitely check it out.

The art, as you can imagine distinguishes this anime from the get-go, putting it closer to "Aku no Hana" and further from most sports anime. Accordingly, the story is leaning a lot on the characters& their struggles through the lens of the sport, not that much on the sport itself.
Plot-wise, expect a classic sports anime set up that doesn’t stray too much from that, complete with a tournament arc. It does have a full ending though which is always a big plus.
A top player who tries as hard as he possibly can, does everything mechanically, just to win. Winning is expected, not fun.
A skillful player
                  who is afraid to win, so he prefers to run and hide from his bullies and personal demons.
An arrogant player who talks big but now can't land a single point against a strong opponent. He promised to be a hero, but the hero never came.
Old players, trying to keep the new ones from repeating their mistakes.
The way the characters interact with each other and is great, learning and overcoming their problems& growing stronger accordingly. All of them have very different issues, so it’s not repetitive.
The animation is a big selling point, as it can warp and bend in accordance with the directors ideas, without hesitating to go past what’s pretty. This is a critical point that quite a few watchers might not be able to go past. It really fits the plot though, adding a gritty quirkiness and is a big part of the anime. Without it, I think the anime would lose a lot of its appeal.
Personally, even though I appreciated all of the above this anime didn't quite hit the mark to go above a "good". As I mentioned, the characters and their development was good, but plot wise it didn’t hold many surprises and was pretty weak. Most side characters were neutral to indifferent and aside from very few points I couldn’t bring myself to cheer for the main 3 characters. Art was fitting, not exceptional, but it carried the show nonetheless. 
Overall: Worth checking if you have the time and feel free to decide on your own!

Honestly I didn't think I would like it as much as I did, but a friend of mine really likes this anime (says it's his favourite), so for his birthday I said I'd watch it lol. No regrets.
The story really had me invested all the way through, and it made me care for each character individually, especially Smile and Kong (the Chinese was great and not cringy which is a plus), they were my favourite. The animation and visual was interesting, never seen anything like it before but I feel like it added to the story.
I really liked the stuff about hardworking vs talent and
                  the crude reality of only having hardworking sometimes isn't enough and you need both to really be at the top. 
I am disappointed at who won the match in the final game, I wanted it to be the other player (if you've watched it you know who I mean) But I love how it wrapped everything up in the end.

Ping pong the animation is probably the best show to give a full character arc in 11 episodes. And it does it for four separate characters. This show is great at a lot of things, but I rated is as a masterpiece because it led us through a genuine journey. This is a show that is about the characters, and how they deal with life and their philosophy through ping pong. I cry my way through the final arc every few months since I watched it initially in the beginning of last year. The art is interesting and strange, but you’ll grow to love and
                  appreciate it. The cinematography is unlike much else I’ve ever seen outside of western comic book movies, but is done in such an interesting and unique way that it feels brand new. I can’t recommend this show enough.

Just got done watching the show a few minutes ago and it was a masterpeice The way the show makes you feel like your in those ping pong games in the audience is great. It like your always on the edge of your seat watching these characters learning more about them each episode. This was extremely enjoyable and super fun and also this is my first port anime lol. i really love the animation its kinda like a manga cause they split the scene up a bit sometimes. The characters are cool sometimes funny i really like the main character i kinda relate to him
                  a bit. Not gonna spoil but i think the end was perfect. The music was relaxing and clam and it fit the vibe of the scene.

Blood tastes like iron. We are all alive. Table tennis is a freaking blast.
This anime might not change your life, but it explores inspiring themes like the benefits of hard work, what it truly means to follow a passion, and what loving life is all about. This show is the most concise, meaningful, and complete display of humanity I have seen in any media.
The amazing soundtrack that always perfectly match the feeling of a scene, the unique art style that exudes emotion and life, the phenomenal screenplay that pulls your heart in all directions, and the deeply empathetic characters that each represent a different way
                  of interaction with passion, evolving as players and humans, give this show not only depth unlike anything else I've ever seen, but a feeling of pure fun through and through.
Every time I come back to it, the lens through which I think about the themes has changed because of my own growth, and it never fails to give me new wisdom.
I recommended this show to all of my friends and I am pissed that they haven't watched it yet, which is why this review HAD to be written. It needed to come out one way or another.
Ping Pong is just that good.

In my Mononoke review, I stated: "I doubt I'll be coming across anything quite this jawdropping any time soon".
Well...
...
I was fucking wrong.
Ping Pong the Animation was directed by the great Masaaki Yuasa and is the official anime adaptation of the word "Passion"--as well as the original 90s manga, of course.
Everything about this show revolves around this concept.
"Passion".
"What is your passion?""What brings out the passion in you?"
"WHO brings out the passion in you?"
Perfectly illustrated by how it chooses to focus (not just address, FOCUS) on many different Ping Pong players and how each one perceives and relates to the titular sport. As said in the show: "Who do you play for?" Sure, there may be the two REAL main characters, Smile and Peco, but the show still manages to go out of its way to flesh-out every character who seems to be in any way "important" to the narrative. (One random, seemingly expendable, dude loses once and, instead of having his story end there, we constantly get glimpses of where he chooses to roam after said defeat) Touches like these are what make the narrative feel so real and touching. I mean, THAT and all the visual metaphors that are thrown in once in a while as to better illustrate what the characters are feeling (the most prominent ones being The Hero and The Robot). Plenty were the times where I found myself in tears, be it from sadness or from pure untamed JOY.
All this being achieved in less than 5 hours, mind you.
Now, I could easily end this review here and call it a day, but... That'd be doing a HUGE disservice to all the staff involved.
Every faced of this production seems to have been miteculously crafted into a most beautiful whole, thanks in no small part, to the great Masaaki Yuasa himself.
The OST was incredible, the voice acting was impeccable all around, the pacing was "yo mama's PUSS" levels of tight and the visuals... Oh, mah boy, the visuals. They may turn some people away at first but they have at least three major points in its favor that completely invalidade any "supposed" faults anyone could see.
First- Objectively, the animation looks super fluid.
Second- It's intentionally like that so it can stay close to the original source material.
Third- It looks unique amongst this sea of same-y designs and styles we seem to be getting.
And a surprise fourth reason:
It strengthens the inspirational message it aims to achieve. Having it look this "cheap" and "unprofessional" automically makes the overall product look like an underdog in and of itself. It's like something ANYONE could draw. A 5 year old, with enough practice, could pobably draw something similar to this so maybe YOU could maybe get this far one day too.
(Not really. The proportions are too precise for just anyone to replicate... But the illusion's still there).
I try imagining this as a normal looking shounen and I (no joke) cringe.
What we have is great. What we have is special. What we have is near perfect.
What we have...
Let's us fly.
PS: I don't even like Ping Pong.
